1 male
, “Manchuria / Chandaochedzi // Chicago NHMus / M. Bernhauer / Collection” (median lobe was pulled off by somebody, glued on PC with the body) ( FMNH ).

Diagnosis.
Aleochara coreana
is externally very similar to the other Japanese congeners, especially
A. curtula
,
A. postica
, and
A. parens
, but it can be discriminated from them by the combined following characteristics: body size medium to relatively large (
A. parens
often small-sized); dorsal surface rather finely punctured (not
A. postica
); elytra uniformly yellowish to reddish brown without lateral dark maculations (not
A. curtula
and some of
A. postica
); median lobe of male aedeagus bulbous (not
A. postica
), no hook-like shaped at apex (not
A. curtula
), with complex sclerites reaching to almost basal margin of median lobe (not
A. parens
), and by; non-deformed female spermatheca (not
A. postica
), with only small apical invagination of spermathecal head and coarsely striate inner walls (not
A. curtula
). Restricted to only mainland and adjacent large islands in Japan .

Body ( Figs 1 , 10 ): fusiform, robust, medium to large in size; dorsal surface moderately glossy and pubescent, without any types of micro-reticulation, rather finely punctured. Color ( Figs 1 , 10 ): usually uniformly black to blackish brown, but elytra variable in color, generally yellowish to reddish brown uniformly including lateral margins, without any types of dark maculations; antennae with antennomeres I–III pale to dark brown, antennomere IV much darker, antennomeres V–XI slightly darker than those of I–III but covered with minute whitish setae densely; mouth parts and legs pale yellowish brown to dark reddish brown; pubescence yellowish brown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 45–51. Terminalia of
Aleochara ( Aleochara ) coreana
: 45, male tergite VIII, dorsal view; 46, female tergite VIII, dorsal view; 47, male sternite VIII, ventral view; 48, female sternite VIII, ventral view; 49, median lobe of male aedeagus, lateral view; 50, ditto, parameral view; 51, female spermatheca. Scale bars: 0.5 mm (45–48); 0.2 mm (49–50); 0.1 mm (51).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Japan (Hokkaidô, Honshû, Shikoku, Kyûshû; Okushiri-tô Is., Tsu-shima Is.); North Korea , South Korea , China .
Host records. No host record is available.

Remarks for type material.
According to
Park et al . ( 2011 )
,
Aleochara lewisia
is represented by only the holotype and is regarded as a synonym of
A. coreana
. There are, however, two syntypes in BMNH and FMNH . Also, according to the original description, it seems that multiple type specimens were used. The syntype of
A. lewisia
in BMNH is considerably smaller than the syntypes of
A. coreana
(e.g.,
Fig. 107
), and the shape of the aedeagus is slightly different from that of
A. coreana
. However, the general structures of the median lobe and the paramere are almost the same as those of
A. coreana
. In contrast, the syntype of
A. lewisia
in FMNH is medium in size, and male genitalic structures were identical to those of
A. coreana
. The syntype of
A. lewisia
in BMNH is considered to be an individual variation of
A. coreana
.

Type materials of
A. coreana
were collected from Seiskin and Pu Ryong, Korea .

Comments. This is probably the most common
Aleochara
species in Japan . Numerous specimens were found across all of mainland Japan (
Fig. 121
). Many
A. coreana
specimens have been identified erroneously as either
A. curtula
or
A. parens
. Japanese records of
A. coreana
are limited to only
A. lewisia
, which was already synonymized with
A. coreana
.
